commentBody: What no comments? Is there some big event going on in the US tonight or something?
That was a fun theme. The puzzle was a bit heavy on geography but some of us like it that way. And I suspect I'm not the only one who who answered the Steve Kornacki clue while watching him on TV.

I’ve been avoiding election coverage, preferring to get the news in the morning, so I’ll break the ice.  I enjoyed the answer within an answer feature in this pleasant Wednesday exercise.  I wanted green roll to be wad, had to settle for SOD.  I was happy to see the lovely and vociferous MEADOWLARK feature in one of the theme answers.  Sadly, these cheery denizens of open fields are becoming scarcer as open fields become scarcer.
A pretty chewy and  very enjoyable Tuesday puzzle. Thanks for a pleasurable break!
Most excellent Wednesday in a long while, nicely done Mr. Aaronson. My mind may have been elsewhere, but this was 6 minutes over my average.
Should have had a Sunday sized puzzle as a longer distraction tonight…

3 more hours until a 6  year streak bites the dust. It’s small potatoes, but there’s a lot of work and sweat and perseverance in there. Nevertheless, I’m a lifelong union member, and I don’t cross picket lines.

A tough puzzle on a very tough night. Riffling through all the possible fills was so much better than trying to deal with all the possible vote outcomes—a tough slot to fill, a Wednesday puzzle that dropped on this second Tuesday in November, one that feels like a BLACK SABBATH.

My deepest thanks, Adam Aaronson, for a fine, engaging puzzle that offered some welcome relief from this unremitting gloom.
I’m too upset to puzzle.
I'm not starting my new streaks until after the strike, but dang, I sure could use some puzzles to keep me from falling into despair.
I'm trying to remember whether 7A has *ever* been correct, but it's certainly not in the modern day.

I aced this puzzle in 34 minutes.  What?  I haven't yet read the description nor understand the some of the clues.  Shocked by being the 16th commenter.   I'm avoiding knowing the outcome of the election by doing puzzles, although I did cry a little tonight for the world.

There was a cabaret and there was a Master of Cerеmonies. 

It was the end of the world

And I was dancing with Sally Bowles and we were both fast asleep...

I enjoyed solving this puzzle and thought the theme was quite clever.  There were quite a few amusing clues as well.

I don't know much about unions so I don't know if solving this puzzle is crossing a picket line or if it will affect anything one way or the other, but too late now I guess.

I don't have much enthusiasm right now, I have a feeling I'm going to sink into a deep depression tomorrow (and I'm not even from the US!)
The puzzle was fun, thanks.  The US elections, not so much.  :(

Nice and easy Wednesday puzzle including my favorite hard rock band.

Looks like with the two first across answers the constructor has predicted the election result...
Waking up to the news this morning was not a very pleasant experience. My thought are with you, America.
Not to take away from Mr Aaronson, who made an absolutely lovely puzzle that aired on a very unfortunate day. Thank you for providing at least some respite, I thoroughly enjoyed it.

We stopped Strands/Connections/Wordle yesterday.  I'm still struggling to understand why the Mini and this puzzle are not included in the Union's request to respect their picket line.  I see the comments on Wordle and Connections are just as robust as they have been in the past.
While MEAD is fermented from honey, it is not generally sweetened, and often a very dry wine.

Managed to get through this one, though I never really caught on to the trick. No big deal. Not surprised that I'm not alone in not being terribly interested in the puzzle this morning. And... I also see that I'm not the first one to mention the possibility of moving to Canada. Anyway... a couple of puzzle finds today. Here's one of them: A Sunday puzzle from July 15, 2012 by Randolph Ross with the title: "A" trip around the world. First theme clue and answer: "Four stops on "A" trip around the world :" AFRICASIARGENTINARUBA And all the theme answers had the clue: "Three more stops." The other theme answers: AMERICARIZONALBANIA ALGERIALABAMARCADIA ALBERTALAMEDASTORIA ALTOONARMENIARALSEA ANTARCTICALASKANTIGUA Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/15/2012&g=26&d=A ...

I woke up, turned on the news and was instantly completely depressed.  

It helped a bit to have this fine puzzle to concentrate on. I really enjoyed gradually seeing how the fun theme emerged.  An excellent puzzle and just right for a Wednesday I think.  

Well done Adam
My time was closer to my Thursday average than Wednesday’s.  I liked the theme.

Oh Wordle -- did you really havr to do that today of all days?

Was just hanging onto my Times Subscription for the puzzles -- I'm rethinking this decision now.

That may be the sun setting in the picture, and I hate the news, but the fire ball came back up today, and it still SHINES.



(truly)

I love this oasis we have here.

Fun puzzle.
Sleep deprived so I had 3 typos to speck out,
but an otherwise lovely jaunt.

Hoping for peace and calm for 
each and every single one of you.


🐸 ribbit.

Well, at least there are crosswords.  Coming into a grave new world, at least there are crosswords…

Oh, I really adored this language quirk theme.  What finds!  Furthermore, I loved reading Adam’s notes, learning how much brain work and time went into coming up with these theme answers and perfect revealer – the sign of an artist, the sign of one who is not satisfied with anything less than excellence.  There is beauty and inspiration in that.

This puzzle gifted me with a lovely interlude at the perfect time.  Balm.  Adam, it was so good to see you again in the Times after an absence of almost two years, as I love your puzzles.  Thank you so much for this jewel!

Enjoyable puzzle on a dark day. 
Can someone please explain 56D though?
Did enough of this fine puzzle to guess the theme but will set it aside and come back when I have better focus.  Time for reassessment but this group will be in the list of priorities.
Woke up to find 1A starting the puzzle and in charge of the country.

A puzzle with the flavor of BLACK SABBATH, devilishly clever as it is.

Feeling MOPEY today, with a definite urge to POUT!

Grateful, like several who have already commented, for a community attuned to the beauty, subtlety and power of language, used in other forums to enhance critical thinking and and deepen the understanding of humanistic values.

That's the LONG AND SHORT OF IT!
Only not finding out about the strike - they’re asking us to abstain from Wordle and Connections only?

I'm glad Adam had the patience to sit with this theme until he perfected it. The supporting fill makes me think he knew what was going to happen. I was hoping that this Billy Bragg song would have lost its relevance, but no such luck: https://youtu.be/0K7gyTQuuls?si=bz4mmeMMM60fNRLx
Could someone please explain 68D?

Anyone know what's up with OPE? I thought I was well traveled enough and weird enough to at least recognize most of the nation's idioms, but I've never heard this one. 

Glad to have the puzzle this strange and unsettling morning.
great theme!

ko and I are spending the day wallowing in misery and self pity. We will add a POUT or two.

Thank you Adam. Nice puzzle
A gem of a puzzle. I'm sorry for the constructor that it had to come on such a dark day.
think grid may set a record for pop-culture names (that i have never heard of) and shows (that i have never seen) in a week-day puzzle

I will never be able to unsee what was shown to me in today's puzzle regarding BLACKSABBATH.

In other news, I did not think the Sabbath fell on a Wednesday.
I’m impressed that you wrote a program to help up you with the clues and persevered for years. Kudos to you.
Really well executed theme! Took a tick to follow what was happening with the shaded squares, but they all work so well.

Very clever and fun puzzle. You can't spell BLACK SABBATH without ABBA. I'll just leave this "Into the Void"/"Take a Chance on Me" mash-up here. It's as creepy as you might imagine: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vN8AZY5dOJA
Elegant puzzle!
I just can't. This would have been fun on any other day, but I'm just miserable right now.

"Some people have no faith in this country."
Bert Cooper

So clever!  No wonder it took literally years and both human and technical data processing.

That's two really impressive puzzles in the same week.  My footer is already straining at the seams.

/sorry, rest of the world

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
Evan Kalish 11/5 Runner-Up for 2024

56 down

Just 56 down





Just 56 down
Nice puzzle!  ...If you don't have Adam Aaronson at the very top of your list of notable NYT constructors, then you simply don't know how to alphabetize.  😎

Deb, Caitlin, Joel-
Are you guys on strike?
I would hate to lose my crossword and Wordle streaks, but I am not one to cross a picket line?

I'm writing this comment about nothing, because the comment that I wrote earlier today (a continuation of one that did post) is still in limbo despite my trying seven times to post it, some as a reply, some as a separate post. 

So this is a test...
56-Down is very apt for today

I'm going to try rewriting the conclusion of my other post in the most innocuous way possible, to see if it finally posts after eight other attempts...
___

The main reason I'm still solving and commentingis that I have already bought the right to do so.  I only do harm to myself if I don't use it. 

Let's say I bought a well-known electric car.  And then, because the famous owner of the company decides to support a man who stands for everything I stand against; do I stop using my car in protest?  Would I be punishing that guy?  Who am I harming by not using it?  Even if the factory workers walked off their job, would it make sense for me to punish myself?  Especially since I doubt my actions would even be noticed.

Everyone else, you do you.  I'll do me.  Self-interest seems to be in fashion these days, especially when there's nothing to be gained by self-denial.

Good morning. Loving this theme-y week! Thank you for this lovely puzzle. Bright spot on a dark day. 
Re: the strike. I'm not boycotting because I pay yearly, and my subscription runs through next summer. The only person who would suffer if I stopped doing the puzzles is me. If the strike is going on when my renewal comes up, I'll re-think it.

Aw, everybody's so MOPEY today. I just wish I'd been watching MSNBC when they had to call Pennsylvania. That had to have been a crushing BLOW.

In July of 1975, I was standing on the beach on Cape Cod, looking up into the night sky. Sure enough, we were able to see the docked APOLLO and Soyuz, as they sailed overhead in low-Earth orbit. (TIL that the display at the NASM is mostly a model.)
Hermit thrush! Hermit thrush in the deep woods of the north. https://youtu.be/o0mATRdzZSc?si=RPibsVP2vMTdVOcN

Lovely crossword, clever theme. 
I’m sick to my stomach for your country. I just can’t understand why? Why?
It’s 2016 and Brexit again. I can never forgive the lies that were told that people fell for. 8 years later you struggle to find anyone to admit they voted Leave. Its destroyed the UK. I fervently hope today’s choice won’t do the same to the USA.

Hi all — I'd like to ask that you limit any political commentary to the political articles on the site (of which there are many today). I know that that's not easy to do, given how vital this space has become to the community of Times Crossword solvers, but it's likely that comments here expressing political views will be either filtered out or flagged for removal. 

Thanks for your kindness and understanding; let's keep this a hopeful place to be.

LIMEADE… reminds me, today, of when me and Jimmy had a Kool-Aid stand even though the only Kool-Aid in the cupboard was lime flavored. We figured limes were sour, not sweet  like cherries, so we added two or three times the sugar and thought that would make it better
Clever theme, but it left a lot of three-letter words for fill.
Thank you for the delightful puzzle today. Lovely theme. This was a refreshing distraction from what has likely been on all of our minds this morning.
The thought that not doing puzzles will save the union is delusional in more ways than one today.
Tater TOTs can also be baked, in fact that's how I usually prepare them.
Come back soon, America.
A challenging Wednesday, thanks for the much-needed distraction!
Wish i could have enjoyed this, but our nation suffered a major set back yesterday and i am in mourning,

I'm thinking what devil is an "ollid"? And what does "alo" have to do with Toblerone chocolate.

I was beginning to despair when it occured to me that "mopey" is a synonym for my original choice "moody"and magically "ollie" (a skateboard maneuver) and "alp" (a Swiss peak) transformed my "sullen" humor into one of triumph.

Oh, in re the moratorium on political commentary on the Wordplay column, I did start to vent in response to one of the conservative opinion columnists (McCarthy) but eventually I cancelled it.

To paraphrase Gerald Ford "our long national nightmare is just beginning" and  no amount of venting is going to change that!

Last night I tried to thank dutchiris for his/her first post but kept getting a ”try again later” message.  I also mentioned that it was a tough puzzle for me, as I seemed to be looking up everything.  But I don’t regret the time spent as I did finally get through it.  Let us muddle on together.

Speaking of muddling, I just noticed that the quotation marks in my iPad keyboard are the closed version.  Since there is no open option, why not a neutral image?

I shuddered when after 3 turns of playing today's Wordle, this is what I had: 

TRU** 

and thought, well it is a word... but no, they wouldn't dare... 

(I posted this comment earlier, had several replies, and then I noticed later the thread had been removed.  I don't think it was removed by anything that I said, but I did remove the one editorializing sentence from the original post before submitting this comment)

Came here to say:
1. Love this community 
2. I hope they will leave most of your comments stand. It's doing my heart good to read them. 
3. Puzzles, esp. NYT puzzles, are my #1 refuge from life and I'm not giving that up for anything. Even for a few days.

I thought this was a very clever theme. I was stalled at the end for a while because there is a sandal called "DEVO," and "BOSSO"and "RIBBID" both looked right to me. I finally gave in and read the column, which set me straight. Thanks for the fun on this anything-but-fun day.

A lot of issues going on today which have and will continue to impact today’s forum. To lighten things up, I have a crossword related tidbit some might find mildly interesting. Last Sat 8/17/2024 we had a clue at 7D,  [One-named poet from the 13th century], solving to RUMI, which had been similarly clued three times previously. Caitlin didn’t mention the entry in the column and I don’t remember much discussion of it in the forum. Well today I was watching the latest episode of  “Itchy Boots” (season 8, episode 8) and she (the Dutch motorcycling Ph.D. geologist who vlogs her trips on YouTube) visited his tomb in Konya, Turkey. I recognized the name right away! Look it up, maybe….
I see a lot of puzzles in my next 4 years.
This puzzle was a really nice distraction. It was clever, amusing, and just the right degree of difficulty for a trying Wednesday. Thank you Adam Aaronson!

Nice puzzle. Very clever.  

I'd like to go on, especially about OPE, but I can't.

Sorry that this really nice, clever puzzle fell on a day where I can't muster up any enthusiasm.
I looked through many of the comments on this sad day, but did not see anybody ask about the answer to 57 down. Can someone please explain it to me? Thanks.
Seems hard for wednesday...can't wait to do it tonight.

This is a reply to Mr. Dave, who asked me whether I would renew my subscription during the current job action.  (It wouldn't post as a reply.)

Probably, since my subscription renews automatically, and I wouldn't know until after it happens.  Would it bother me?  Probably not.

I worked for 40 years as a union member (United Federation of Teachers) and never once had to go out on a job action, although I am grateful for those brave teachers who did in the 60s to create the professional environment I worked in (and messed up my eighth grade quite a bit).  Had I ever had to do so, I wouldn't have cared if parents chose to send their schools anyway (in the 60s, they were kept open for those who needed child care).  After all, it would be the teachers' absence that mattered, not the students'.

A welcome distraction from today’s feeling of mourning. Someone please wake me up from this nightmare. Still in shock. But one thing I have to mention is that two of my all time fave bands are in this! BLACK SABBATH and ABBA. Deep love for both groups!!

One last impassioned plea to get some sort of understanding of the moderation system.  Anything really, except for another quiz.

It is causing great grief with all your paying customers, even the important ones.  Just look below at the accusations of being called a liar, concerning the way it works or does not work.

It you don't do something this time, that indicates that you have no interest in providing a clean, reliable service, and I'll be cancelling for good.

What a delightful puzzle. Really loved seeing the alternative theme entries as well. If I have any complaints, it’s that I don’t believe that the word OATY has ever been used outside a crossword. Still, whenever I solve a puzzle using it, it always makes me roll my eyes and chuckle.

@Ant Hmmm .... I read somewhere that something is going on..... There's also the strike. I just saw this as well. https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/04/business/media/new-york-times-strike.html?smid=nytcore-android-share
@Jenny Thanks for mentioning the strike. I should have paid more attention to the labor situation at the Times and, as much as I enjoyed this puzzle, shouldn't have played it tonight.

@Marshall Walthew
Me, too. Scared to look at election coverage. Puzzle was too easy to keep me away until the polls close in California.  Very enjoyable, maybe the Mini will fill my time until 8 pm PST.

@bratschegirl -- Bit over eight years for me.  I'm hoping the strike ends soon, then I can fill in the unfilled grids in order, and maybe the streak will stand?  Some people here in the past have said that that works.  But if not, c'est la vie.

@Lewis

I’ve noticed that as long as I complete the puzzles in order and don’t open a new puzzle before finishing the oldest one my streak will stand. For example if I finished yesterday’s puzzle today and don’t open today’s puzzle my streak is saved.

@dutchiris 

After reading the comments, I see  that I should not have been so focused on what was happening nationally and paid more attention to what was happening here.  My sympathy to the tech workers who make all this possible, and my apologies for not observing your picket line.

@dutchiris

I’m going to rage-quit this country. See you in Lillehammer.
@Jim -- According to Rex Parker, if you solve the puzzle in the hard copy newspaper, or use a third party app, you are not crossing the picket line, since the strike only involves the digital realm.

@Lewis 
I find Rex's saying that using a third party app is ok bogus. One is  still making use of the digital  product.

@Jim 

There are always the printed NYTCP collections available on Amazon.

@Boris

Well I guess the idea is that it was at some point limited to institutions of higher education. Like .gov was limited to government entities. And presidents were limited to non-convicts. 

But now God knows,
Anything Goes
Then again, I was wrong about the answer, so I've had an Emily Litella moment.

@Boris

God bless Gilda.

@Boris After 2001, per https://net.educause.edu/eligibility.htm only US-based accredited institutions of higher education can register an edu domain. From the site it sounds like there are some grandfathered cases that have maintained their registration.

@Boris 

It's .org that no longer means anything
oh dear I hadn't heard about the strike

@Janine

Got an extra room or two? Think Canada’s about to have an explosion of entry applications.
@Harri also 3D, 56D, maybe 7D and 15D, 12D for sure, 35D perhaps?
@Harri Torille! Your comment made me chuckle, fully agree with the sentiment. Terveisiä naapurista :)

@Harri 
Oh, you're a big fan of EUROPE? (It's the Final Countdown!) I'm kidding, BLACK SABBATH may have been the first cassette I bought with my own money. I never got to see them live, but I did see Ozzy, solo. (No bats were harmed.)
@Sonja Kiitos, indeed it is a dark day in American history. Hang on, it's going to be a bumpy ride.

@John Carson I don't know how many jillions of people play Wordle, but they don't have to be Times subscribers and I don't think they need to be Games subscribers to do so. So how would they even know that the union has asked them to stop? In this article, it says that the Tech union only asks people to not play popular games like Wordle and Connections and not use the Cooking app. Maybe the crossword isn't considered popular? https://nyguild.org/post/new-york-times-tech-guild-walks-off-the-job I haven't found anything directly from the TU online yet. I don't see how just not doing puzzles helps the union. What does the Times care about that? I think the only thing they would care about is canceling subscriptions

@Vaer Thanks for that. Steve L has some recent and similar commentary on this above. I did not realize that the union was formed in 2022 and are seeking their first contract. https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/04/business/media/new-york-times-strike.html?unlocked_article_code=1.X04.N9bJ.haaeBniOr7LR&smid=url-share

@Vaer 

"I don't see how just not doing puzzles helps the union." 

I don't know if it has anything to do with the numbers. I do know firsthand that interacting digitally is considered crossing the picket line -- as more and more of our lives move online, so too have picket lines. 

When adjunct faculty at The New School struck in Fall 2022, we were told we couldn't interact digitally with students, full-time faculty, or administrators through any app managed by the university. That extended beyond school email, grading platforms, etc to Discord, which my students used for messaging with each other and faculty. So it was no-go, even though it had zero bearing on the school itself. 

At The New School, pretty much all full-time faculty walked out in solidarity -- a huge risk for them. I don't see the same here -- for example, with this column. Though of course academia and corporate are (still 🤞) largely different employment environments...!

@G 

What the strikers may or may not do and what other parties do are two different things.  There's no equivalency.

@Jan Wolitzky 

Nor is LIMEAID actually sweet. 

And yet, both* beverages are made using a sweetener. (*In fact, there is a salted lime drink very popular in South Asia, but that's beside the point...)

Any suggestions on a better phrasing for the clue? 

Worked just fine for me...




🍯

@suejean 

LFG

@Murhatroid “The project suffered a blow (major setback) when the team leader left the company.”

@Murhatroid 
Sunny here, finally.

@Rocky 

The article said "popular NYT Games such as Wordle and Connections". People are assuming that means the crossword as well.

@ad absurdum Across? 

On The Other Hand
D. Miele, OPE, Sorry. Hope this helps: https://www.thenorthwestern.com/story/life/2020/05/04/ope-sorry-deeper-look-into-midwests-favorite-expression/3003713001/
@Barry Ancona Thx for that. I have no recollection of ever hearing someone use that….but now I’m sure I’ll hear it all the time!
@Barry Ancona Interesting! Definitely have never heard this, but now I will never forget it. It's amazing how much I've gleaned over the years from doing the x-word. Thank you.

@Barry Ancona Interesting! Definitely have never heard this, but now I will never forget it. It's amazing how much I've gleaned over the years from doing the x-word. Thank you. Sounds oddly Filipino, actually, from family experience. Funny that it comes from the American Midwest!

@BA
Thanks for this, your linked video is pretty cute. I haven’t spent any time in that part of the country and the clue/answer went right by me.

😮 OPE!

—  —  —  —

—  —  —  —

@Hardroch

I should point out that OPE has appeared something like 250 or so times since 1942! Today, I believe was the first time it was clued  to a midwestern expression. I see Rex cited BA’s article as well. good stuff….

😮😮😮😮

—  —  —  —

—  —  —  —

@Mr Dave 

Almost all of the 88 times during the Modern Era (since apparently, we're in the post-Shortz Era), not to mention the previous eras, OPE has been clued as a poetic version of "open", with words like "unlock", "expose", "poetically," and "in verse" predominating in the clues.  

One clue was based on an Eliza Doolittle pronunciation of "hope", but today's is the only clue I see that used this tack.

And I hope you see that when Barry (or I) mention that a word is a frequent visitor in the Archives, it's to make people aware of a word they should know for next time, and not to lecture them.

(I did notice the "smile" at the end of your post.)

@Barry Ancona
Thanks for that article. I wondered about OPE also, having lived in the Chicago area for much of my adulthood, before eventually returning to my home state. We learn so many interesting things from crosswords and from our fellow solvers.

@Barry Ancona For those who don't know, the "student" in the video is Charlie Berens, University of Wisconsin J-school graduate who morphed into a comedian, poking gentle, but spot-on, fun at midwestern language and behaviors. His short YouTube videos could be an enjoyable diversion in these dark times. Not to be missed is "Midwest Siri." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_8n2q5iI4E First time in my life I'm embarrassed to be from the Badger state, although Milwaukee, the UW and Dane County did all they could.

@Mr Dave 

I really don't think anyone else does that for that reason...and of course I know I don't.  I think maybe it's just how you're reading it.  If I'm wrong, point it out the next time it happens.  I'll keep my eye out.
@Justin omg this is amazing! I never saw this mashup. I love both bands to death

Steve,

Of course the "nothing" post appears right away...

@Barry Ancona 

And by reworking the offending conclusion, with other words that kept the exact same meaning, I finally got the "something" post to go through.

Who can explain?

(And how did you get your short post through?)
The algorithm changed a few weeks ago.

@Barry Ancona 

Wait - are you saying anti-emu padding is no longer effective?  Necessary?

___________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Barry Ancona 

Wow!

@Francis 

You are absolutely incorrect.  The thing is, the rules were different for different people, and you had to be a very frequent commenter to have been affected by that rule.  (Although I'm surprised you weren't affected, since I think of you as a frequent commenter, but perhaps not quite at the threshold that was set.)

I did some experiments at that time, sending brief and longer messages one after the other, and the longer messages always got through while the brief messages didn't.

It took the community a while to realize that it didn't affect everyone equally.

So why is it so hard for some of those whom it didn't affect to understand that it really did exist for a substantial period of time?  Do you think we're making it up?

It does appear it's been changed, since my "Wow!" to Barry did go through.  Halla-ma-lujah!

@Steve L 

Do you realize that the "length" of a message is determined by the number of characters it contains?

So a series of return/new line characters barely increases the length of a post, just the white space when it appears.

I doubt very much the veracity of your "experiments".

@Steve L 


"Do you think we're making it up?"

No, I think you're finding patterns in something which is essentially patternless.

It's easy to do.  We all do it all the time.

@Francis 

Actually, through trial and error, we determined that line spacing had a lot to do with it.  I don't really know why this was the case, or how it was technically possible.

I'm really not surprised you don't take me at my word that this phenomenon actually exists and several of us have experiences to bear it out. People just seem to believe whatever they want to believe these days, and that was made most clear today of all days.

I would prove it all to you right now with a new experiment, but apparently, the rules are different now.  I did just that for other people when the doubts were raised back when it was happening, but people continued to disbelieve anyway.

I feel for Galileo.

@Steve L 

I really wonder if you, as a member of the illuminati of this community, realize how there is a that runs roughshod over everyone else.

I generally agree with defenders of the puzzles, and I often agree with BA.  I tried very hard to be as supportive as I could of constructors and cluers, often writing supportive comments.

Even so I've been smugly and summarily dismissed and given the back of the hand for any tiny indiscretion that seems critical of the elite, ant that makes it clear that only a few are really welcome here.  That the results of my "experiments".

And I tried very hard to be a positive member of the community.  I tried to always encourage and praise new commenters, who were celebrating a cheatless solve, who were happy about a streak.

I rarely saw such comments from the elite.

I know you think you are right.  But if you really can't "know why this was the case, or how it was technically possible", then I think any rational thinker would doubt the conclusion.

I, too, feel for Galileo.

@Francis 

I don't know why skipping lines has the desired effect of making the entry pass muster, but it does.  Just like I don't know the details of how when I put my foot on the accelerator, my car goes forward, but I know how to drive.

In neither case do I think someone is waving some kind of magic wand.  But I do know that I've had problems posting one line, which disappear when I add a paragraph of filler to it.  Or even a bunch of !!!!'s.

Choose to believe me--and the others who have discovered the same thing--or don't.  But I won't be there to rescue you when you fall off your flat earth.

Sometimes, things don't post for other reasons.  That muddles up the situation and leads some people to believe that every instance of stuff not appearing is some other reason.  

Of course, it's all moot now that it's apparently been fixed.

Sorry if I'm coming off as hostile.  It's just that I find it mindboggling you're willing to die on this hill that adding the filler never served any purpose.  And somewhat disrespected, because it's tantamount to calling me a liar.  Or if I really just think I'm right, then a pathological liar.  Which brings us back to last night...

@Francis I, too, have tried the experiment. Submitted a very short one and immediately after, one with the same text but slightly longer. The one with added lines posted immediately and the one with same words, on one line, was held up for several hours.

Yesterday I submitted a short post without thinking and it was held up, had not appeared by the time I left. My long one posted immediately. The short one was innocuous, agreeing with someone else's innocuous post. The _only_ times I have had posts not show up immediately was with the two tests and then yesterday.

@Lynn 

With all due respect, I haven't had the same experience.  I have had *many* very short posts appear immediately, both now and in the past.  I think I have a right to draw conclusions about my own experience, just as you claim that right.

And once again, I've not heard any explanation for why an electronic moderation unit that has no knowledge of "blank space", rather only ASCII symbols that translate into "go to a new line", somehow measures the blank space.

I've also had many long posts that didn't show up for hours.

And by the way, you are contradicting Barry, who says that it's been "fixed".  So your short posts should be showing up immediately.

Which is another way of saying I can't repeat the experiment so there must be something different now, rather than something wrong with the experiment.

I've been a scientist all my life.  It's astonishing how difficult it can be to do an experiment without confounding uncontrolled parameters.

And this is another reason why I've pleaded with the NYT to be forthcoming about their moderation practices.  Their unwillingness to do this is causing rifts between people who, at least at one time, seemed to like one another.

@Steve L 

Here's the first part:

I'll begin by articulating my approval of this puzzle, which contains a theme I don't recall ever having seen before.  We've had words within words, but not that answer the clue just as well as the larger word, i.e. two examples in the same category.

I wish I were as sanguine about last night's results.  I wonder how over 50% of the country has collective amnesia and doesn't consider moral bankruptcy--if not actual bankruptcy--a disqualifier for the position of President.  And I wonder why that same majority would choose that person over his opponent--are they still unwilling to elect a female president?  How much of a handicap was her being a minority?

Whatever, this country seems intent upon voting against their own best interests.

But let's move onto the minor controversy on all the commenters' minds:  how to react to the NYT tech workers' strike. I for one will continue to solve the puzzles and participte.  Why?  First of all, I very sincerely doubt that my absence--or the absence of every person who said they would abstain--will have any effect whatsoever on the outcome of the strike.  Note how little effect--none, actually--all the pleading had when it was announced that the Acrostic would be discontinued online.  Your "voice" is just not that noticeable.

In fact, if anything, more traffic could lead to issues developing that might prove the worth of those workers, more so than less traffic would.

@David Connell - I see comments about ope and its clue today. It is akin to nope, yep, and others in that the final p is unreleased. The sound ends with a closed mouth. This is why BZZT and PSST are spelled as they are (lots of folks hated on the former): the sound is stopped and not released. That unreleased sound is extremely expressive, and reflecting it in writing is equally expressive. No and nope are distinct; yeh/yeah and yep are distinct. There are definable differences between them. The unreleased plosive expresses finality, decisiveness, confidence, strongly held opinion.

Mm-hmm. Uh-hunh. Unh-hunh. Nuh-unh. Nuh-hunh. Naw. Nah. No. Nope. Nowise. Nohow. Gradation.

Lesley, IOTA is a Greek letter but it is an English word. There is no foreign language signal needed in the clue. "W" is also a [Three-syllable letter] but DoubleU won't fit in four squares without a rebus or two or three. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/iota

IOTA is the English word for the Greek letter.

This is the Greek word for it: ιώτα
